Award.AbstractNarration:
PROGRAM DIRECTOR'S RECOMMENDATION
1338925 George Mason University; Chaowei Yang
1338914 Harvard University; Peter Bol
1338902 University of California-Santa Barbara; Keith Clarke

George Mason University (GMU) as the lead institution, Harvard University (HU), and the University of California Santa Barbara (UCSB) are proposing to establish a center for spatiotemporal thinking, computing and applications.

The proposal seeks to establish an I/UCRC for spatiotemporal thinking, computing and applications as a collaborative platform among industry, university, government agencies, and other organizations to advance this domain of knowledge. The proposed center will be established based upon the previous successes at each of the three sites including: a) the Center for Intelligent Spatial Computing (CISC) at GMU for spatiotemporal computing/software development; b) the Center for Spatial Studies (CSS) at UCSB for spatial thinking and analyses; and c) the Center for Geographic Analysis (CGA) at Harvard for spatiotemporal applications.

The mission of the new Center would be to integrate these technologies into a comprehensive spatiotemporal theory and applications. Research results and success stories will be disseminated through publications in relevant spatiotemporal venues as well as among the center member sites for adoption and outreach. The PIs plan to use their established relationship with leading organizations to broadcast the research results and recruit new members through the organization channels. The PIs plan to develop new curriculum within existing degree programs at the three sites, and to continue their diversity traditions to include minorities and other underrepresented groups in center activities

POR.DRECONTENT:
Everything happens at some place, some time. Satellites, Global Positioning Systems, the Internet of Things, social media, and many other technologies generate data with location and time properties in an unprecedented manner. It is critically important to acquire superior knowledge of spatiotemporal principles, build computational infrastructure capable of processing big spatiotemporal data efficiently, and gain insights on how to apply these principles and capabilities to solve real-world problems. Furthermore, it is also important to develop educational programs with state-of-the-art spatiotemporal curricula in order to understand our world better, to respond to regional and global emergencies in a timely way, and to prepare the next generation’s workforce.

This project formed the Spatiotemporal Innovation Center, a research consortium through collaboration among George Mason University, University of California at Santa Barbara, and Harvard University, together with industry, government agencies and other organizations. The Center conducted theoretical research, system development, and educational dissemination on spatiotemporal principles, methodologies and applications. It began building a national and international spatiotemporal infrastructure to advance human intelligence through spatiotemporal thinking; computer software and tools through spatiotemporal computing; and human capability of responding to deep scientific questions and grand engineering challenges through spatiotemporal applications and education.

The Center served as a platform for academia, industry, and agencies to collaborate to achieve fundamental and discipline-wide results. Members from academia received unique opportunities to interact with industry and agencies to understand real world problems and research needs. Industry members gained access to research results, incorporated them into their operations for better efficiency, or turned them into future products and services to improve their competitiveness. The products, services, and operations served a wide range of end users from the public and K-16 to professionals.

From September 2013 to August 2019, Harvard University researchers presented to the Industry Advisory Board (IAB) 33 research proposals. Among them, seven received funding from the IAB. Some were completed in 1-3 years, others are continuing through multiple years. Several projects were conducted in collaboration with researchers at the other sites, and with industry members and partners. Through developing research proposals and conducting funded research projects, researchers identified unmet needs and challenges in spatiotemporal theory, methodology, technology and application across academic fields, developed solutions to address them, and disseminated these solutions broadly to industry and university users. Some examples of key research outcomes include:

  • Established Open Geospatial Consortium approved standards for hydrologic features’ semantic web ontology.
  • Built a prototype platform for interactive query and visualization of a billion streaming spatiotemporal objects.
  • Jointly with an industry member, developed critical geospatial functionality for a GPU-powered SQL database, and built use-cases to demonstrate its ability for rapid query and visualization of big spatiotemporal datasets.
  • Jointly with industry members and partnering universities, built geospatial capacity in 11 selected secondary cities which are in developing countries with large population, weak governance and a lack of operational data and infrastructure. This multi-year project created a common geospatial dataset for each of the participating cities on an open source geospatial data management and sharing platform (GeoNode).

 

Research results from these and other projects were presented in international conferences or symposiums; published in Geographic Information System (GIS) journals or books; shared as code packages in GitHub (https://github.com/cga-harvard), posted on the center website (https://www.stcenter.net/), and circulated as center published newsletters, posters or flyers. Platforms developed by this project are publicly accessible (as approved by the sponsoring board members). In addition, the Harvard team in the Center devoted much effort in education and knowledge dissemination, including:

  • Hosted five conferences and symposiums at Harvard University, each with 60-120 participants and 10-30 speakers.
  • Co-organized seven symposiums, five of them as a special track at the American Association of Geographers (AAG) annual meetings from 2014-2018, and two at George Mason University in 2015 and 2016.
  • Published seven peer-reviewed journal articles, two proceeding papers, two technical reports, one book, and one book chapter.
  • Gave 42 oral presentations in national and international conferences.
  • Trained eight undergraduate research fellows in five summers.
